Award.AwardTitle: Supply Chain Consolidation and Cooperation in the Agriculture Industry

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to construct models and design algorithms to (i) optimize the transportation and inventory costs of an agricultural supply chain with small suppliers, perishable product, and a consolidation center, and (ii) allocate the costs of consolidation to the suppliers in a way that encourages participation and sustained cooperation. In particular, the investigators will consider models with small suppliers of quickly perishable agricultural products who would benefit from the economies of scale resulting from consolidation. Models with successively higher levels of consolidation, integration and complexity will be considered, starting with a system that only allows direct shipping through a consolidation center, up to a system that allows routing between the suppliers, the customers, and the consolidation center. Exact methods as well as various heuristics will be developed that take advantage of the natural decomposability of these models. In addition, the investigators will study the associated cooperative game-theoretic problems for these models, focusing on computing fair cost allocations with subsidies or incentives if necessary. The investigators will work closely with the California Cut Flower Commission, which represents California flower growers, in order to develop novel consolidation schemes and cost allocation methods that are both feasible and beneficial in practice.

If successful, this research will result in novel systems for transportation and inventory consolidation in agricultural supply chains with many small suppliers that (i) reduce the total transportation costs for all growers by exploiting economies of scale and full truckload rates, (ii) are simple enough for efficient solution and mostly decentralized control, and (iii) allow for fair cost allocation schemes. In addition, solving these models for transportation and inventory consolidation will require novel algorithmic approaches, combining techniques from transportation science, discrete optimization, and cooperative game theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study (i) transportation consolidation in agricultural supply chains with many small farms as suppliers and (ii) fair methods of allocating the costs of consolidation among these farms. In many agricultural markets, small farms without the production volume required to sustain a transportation fleet rely on third-party carriers to transport their product to customers. Because of their small volume, this transportation entails costly less-than-truckload (LTL) rates and places small farms at a disadvantage.  The disadvantage is aggravated when the growers must compete against imported products with lower labor costs. By consolidating their products for transportation purposes, small farms in the same geographical region can enjoy cheaper full truckload (FTL) rates. However, consolidation does not come without challenges: Although a set of cooperating growers can certainly expect to reduce transportation costs when consolidating, each individual farm may not necessarily reap the benefits. The challenge is to design a system that (i) reduces the total transportation costs for all growers by exploiting economies of scale and FTL rates, (ii) is simple enough for efficient solution and mostly decentralized control, and (iii) allows for fair cost allocation schemes, thus encouraging participation and sustained cooperation by growers.

 Intellectual Merit. The design of a system meeting all these requirements involved combining techniques from transportation science, discrete optimization, and cooperative game theory into a modeling framework for transportation and inventory consolidation.  Models with successively higher levels of consolidation, integration and complexity were developed, starting with a system that only allows direct shipping through a consolidation center, up to a system that allows routing between the suppliers, the customers, and the consolidation center. These models required novel algorithmic approaches, both in optimization and game theory.  Problems in routing are typically difficult to solve, requiring heuristics and/or practically efficient exact techniques.  A cost sharing mechanism that allocated the costs based on a combination of the demand and the capacity of the truck was developed and shown to exhibit a number of desirable properties. The developed heuristic approaches were tested on actual data sets from the California Cut Flower Industry and showed that significant efficiencies could be achieved if growers consolidated their shipments. 

 Broader Impact. Agriculture is a vitally important part of the U.S. economy, accounting for around $100 billion of value added to the economy per year. For some products, small and medium-sized farms grow a significant fraction of the total. Farms in these sectors face low margins and increasing foreign competition, and modern operational strategies such as consolidation are crucial to their survival. One such sector is the flower industry, which faces escalating competition from South American growers, in part because of a recent free trade agreement between the U.S. and Colombia. The investigators worked closely with the California Cut Flower Commission (CCFC), which represents California flower growers, in order to develop novel consolidation schemes and cost allocation methods that are both feasible and beneficial in practice.
